U.S. diversified stock mutual funds extended their rally in February, picking up steam while tacking on 2.68% on average after gaining 1.83% in January, according to Lipper Inc.That reflected gains by the broad stock market, measured by the S&P 500, which advanced 3.97% last month after notching a 1.90% gain in January. But market leadership rotated back to more defensive sectors, reflecting growing caution among investors."The more-defensive stocks did well, while cyclical energy and materials did not outperform," said Lew Piantedosi, who is lead manager of seven Eaton Vance funds, totaling $3.9 billion in assets. "It was a complete reversal from the Q4 postelection market rally, which was a cyclicals rally."Sentiment flipped back in favor of growth-oriented cyclicals after President Trump's address to Congress on the last night of February.But the tilt earlier in February toward cyclicals reflected investors' concern that Trump and the Republican-majority Congress may have a harder time than previously expected in implementing pro-growth policies.Reflecting the optimistic portion of February's market performance, health/biotechnology funds led sectors last month, gaining 6.72%.Among U.S. diversified stock fund categories, S&P 500 index funds led the way with a 3.87% gain.World equity funds lagged U.S. diversifieds, advancing just 1.90%, led by India region funds' 6.08% climb.Taxable bond funds eked out an 0.87% gain on average last month. Emerging markets local currency funds outpaced other taxable categories, rising 1.94%.Piantedosi is guardedly bullish, going forward. "The bull market is in place until proven otherwise," he said. Many investors and market observers have tried to call a market top. But the economy keeps getting better, Piantedosi says. "Corporate earnings keep getting better, and earnings support the market," he added.The wild card that could derail the rally is the political landscape, he warns.As long as the economy stays on track, Piantedosi likes the shift to digital by advertising. "That benefits Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL)," he said. "And Amazon (AMZN) dominates online retail."Another area he likes is biotech, which is producing a parade of treatments for diseases. "Celgene (CELG) is a leader within cancer treatments," he said. "It has an unbelievable pipeline. It is growing earnings north of 20% annually and trades at a 17-times forward multiple, just below the market multiple of 18."IBD'S TAKE: Celgene is ranked No. 2 in IBD's Medical-Biomed/Biotech industry group. See which biomed/biotech firm is No. 1, and check out its easy-to-understand fundamental and technical data at IBD's Stock Checkup.In energy, he likes energy explorer and producer Anadarko Petroleum (APC) and field services provider Halliburton (HAL).He said, "Anadarko is once again profitably growing production, generating significant cash flow and is attractively valued." He added, "Halliburton's exposure is mainly to North American shale, and with oil prices (steady) in the mid-50s, you're starting to see rig counts increase. That increases the need for field services. They put rigs together, service them, replace broken parts and so on."He added, "In consumer discretionary, it's hard to find good names. But there's Advance Auto Parts (AAP). They're an auto parts retailer. That sector is less susceptible to be Amazoned. Their business doesn't require a lot of capital expenditure, so it's a good cash flow type of business. And Advance got a new CEO three or four months ago. He's a supply chain expert, which is what Advance needs."One key reason it is hard for investors to find consumer discretionary that names they like is because so many big-box retailers are getting kicked by online retailers, says James Abate, chief investment officer of Centre Asset Management and manager of its $125 million Select Equity (DHAMX). Add to that the risk that many will be forced to cope with higher costs stemming from the border adjustment tax — basically, a value-added tax on imports — proposed by Trump, Abate says.Names in the sector that he does still like include media company CBS (CBS) and specialty food retailer Whole Foods Market (WFM).Sporting an OK 86 Composite Rating from IBD, CBS is trying to clear a consolidation after a run-up that started in the fall.Whole Foods has a very weak Composite Rating of 20 from IBD and is trading at less than half its late 2013 high.The supermarket chain in January reinstalled co-founder John Mackey as sole CEO.Also, the Trump push for infrastructure construction should benefit a number of telecommunications and utility companies, including Comcast (CMCSA) and Verizon (VZ), Abate says. Comcast has been running up since the election and is near its all-time high. Verizon, range-bound between 57 and 46 since July, is trading near 49, 12% below its 52-week high.Flow-control systems manufacturer Parker-Hannifin (PH) also stands to gain from infrastructure spending. Likewise, Quanta Services (PWR), which provides engineering and construction services. "They should benefit from increased spending on pipelines and energy transmission projects," he said.The market faces risks in the form of geopolitical uncertainty, possible trade wars and rising stock valuations, Abate says. "There's a lot of downside risk facing this market," he said. "I expect a lot of volatility going forward."RELATED:Mutual Fund Managers Cite Tech, Financial, Energy And Industrial Names They Like For '17

Machinery makers Dover Corp. (DOV), Flowserve (FLS), Parker Hannifin (PH) and DXP Enterprises (DXPE) rallied again Thursday on higher oil prices and hopes for more infrastructure spending. Stronger manufacturing data and a Parker Hannifin acquisition also may have helped.U.S. oil prices rose 3.3% to $51.06 on Thursday, after surging more than 9% Wednesday on OPEC's agreement to cut production. Higher prices should spur more exploration and drilling in U.S. shale and elsewhere, boosting machinery makers that have seen profit and sales decline.IBD'S TAKE: U.S. shale plays are big winners from the OPEC deal, but here's why U.S. oil production won't ramp up quickly.Dover, an industrial equipment maker than serves the oil and gas industry among others, climbed 4% to 75.53 at the close on the stock market today. That cleared a buy point of 75, with the stock trading at the highest levels since June 2015. Dover rose 4.1% on Wednesday.Flowserve, which makes flow control products, popped 5.1% to 49.85 Thursday afternoon after climbing more than 5% on Wednesday. Flowserve cleared resistance near 50 and is nearing a traditional buy point of 52.60.DXP Enterprises, which also makes flow control products, rose 3.8% to 34.97, rising intraday to the highest since August 2015. Shares rose 12.8% on Wednesday, clearing a 31.44 buy point.Parker Hannifin rose 3.3% to 143.47, hitting a record high after climbing more than 1% on Wednesday. Parker Hannifin will buy Claracor for $4.3 billion including debt, or $83 a share. Claracor will expand Parker Hannifin's product reach into filtration products. Claracor rose more than 17% to 82.58 by the closing bell.

The economic climate is fine over at Ingersoll-Rand (IR), which reported higher first-quarter earnings and revenue, topped estimates and raised its guidance, driving its stock up sharply early Tuesday.Ingersoll-Rand stock rose 2%, climbing above an eight-month cup-with-handle base.The maker of Trane and American Standard heating and air conditioning systems and Nexia and Thermo King transport temperature control systems said earnings per share minus one-time items  jumped 32% to 50 cents, well above consensus for 37 cents. Revenue edged up fractionally to $2.894 billion. Analysts expected $2.889 billion.Sales in Ingersoll-Rand's flagship climate-control segment rose 3% to $2.21 billion from $2.16 billion and adjusted operating profit for that business surged 9.8%. The company raised its full-year 2016 EPS guidance from continuing operations to $3.95 to $4.10, up from $3.80 to $4 earlier, and well above Wall Street's $3.92 target.The Ireland-based maker of climate control systems sold its remaining equity interest in Hussmann Parent on April 1 as part of a transaction in which Panasonic bought 100% of Hussmann’s shares. Ingersoll-Rand received net proceeds of about $415 million. Its 2016 guidance excludes proceeds from that sale.After its rise Tuesday, Ingersoll-Rand stock was well above both its 10-week and 200-day averages but still within trading range. It boasts a 96 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed most stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.Ingersoll-Rand is in the Machinery-General group, ranked a lofty 14 on IBD's list of 197 industries. Top-rated company in the group is Taylor Devices (TAYD) with a 99 IBD Composite Rating. Taylor Devices dipped 0.1% Tuesday. For other large companies in the group, Illinois Tool Works (ITW) rose 0.9% and Parker Hannifin (PH) rose 0.8%

Robotic exoskeletons have been a fixture in science-fiction movies and futuristic military video games. But the devices have become a reality for medical and physical rehabilitation applications. They serve a niche market today but could soon be a big business as industrial and commercial applications are developed, ABI Research said Monday.In a report titled "Robotic Exoskeletons: Classes, Markets and Applications," ABI predicts that sales could reach $1.9 billion in 2025, up from $68 million in 2015, for a compound annual growth rate of nearly 40%. Unit sales of robotic exoskeletons are projected to hit 108,000 units in 2025, up from 2,500 this year, ABI forecast.The market for robotic exoskeletons is still in its infancy, ABI analyst Dan Kara said in a statement. Lower body exoskeletons, employed as rehabilitation tools or quality-of-life enablers, currently lead the sector, he said.Industrial systems that help workers with heavy lifting, extended standing, squatting, bending and walking are on the way."Social imperatives, military requirements and business needs, supported by technological advances, now make it possible to develop commercially viable exoskeleton systems for a wide variety of applications and markets," Kara said.Market leaders include Cyberdyne, Ekso Bionics, Lockheed Martin (LMT), Parker Hannifin (PH), ReWalk Robotics (RWLK), Honda (HMC) and Toyota (TM).ReWalk stock got a boost after reports last week that the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs has agreed to pay for the company's robotic exoskeleton to help paralyzed soldiers walk again.RELATED:Helping Paraplegics Walk Just The Start For Robot Exoskeletons.

Parker-Hannifin shares have posted steep gains the past two weeks, rising 24% from an October 15 low. The stock is 5% below its June high, climbing the right side of a four-month consolidation.

Large caps are looking tired. A recent check of the Big Cap 20 found 16 stocks that were either late stage or too extended to buy.Leaders have plenty of reasons to be suffering from exhaustion. Yes, many stocks have had a long run, but success doesn't fully explain the tired look of the Big Cap 20. A fresh rotation of new stock names is supposed to keep the lineup at least interesting. But the new names aren't stepping forward to lead.Why is that?Part of the reason is that the expected leadership never won favor. Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) made the Big Cap 20 at the start of the year. In late January, Horton reported quarterly earnings growth of 42%, the best in 10 quarters. But the stock kept falling in the weeks ahead. In late April Horton reported 52% earnings growth and then fell some more.When good earnings growth can't persuade either a stock or its group to advance, it's best to back away. Arguing with the market is folly. In this case, the whole industry went into a decline.Caterpillar (CAT) is another stock that made the Big Cap 20 in early January. Caterpillar reported quarterly earnings growth 160% in late January. The stock began a choppy consolidation after the results.Caterpillar is now about 11% off its high.Sometimes an out of favor old name can show new strength. In early January, Parker Hannafin (PH) raised that hope. The stock made the Big Cap 20. But the motion-control technologies provider couldn't overcome the market. The S&P 500 dropped about 12% in 10 sessions in late January and early February, and Parker Hannafin sank with the market.Big cap bank stocks were another group that garnered generous coverage but never delivered as expected.Earnings growth has not been a problem for most stocks. But the market has had trouble converting good news into stock gains.What's the other part of the problem?The other problem appears to be news-driven. The market's troubles began around the same time that President Trump slapped tariffs on solar panels and washing machines Jan. 22. The list of targets grew from there.Meanwhile, starting in November, China has had three waves of tariff cuts. This has not received much attention, but it could pay off for China.China has trimmed tariffs on avocados, mineral water, strollers, washing machines, refrigerators, cosmetics, drugs, shoes, kitchenware and fitness supplies. Some say the cuts are insignificant.But if those kinds of tariff cuts were to lead to reciprocal actions, the world economy would benefit. And the stock market would likely see some new leaders.RELATED:Like Your Stocks On The Trashy Side? After serving in the U.S. military, some veterans become financial advisors. They find that their Armed Forces experience influences them in positive ways.Financial advisors with a military background often cite their years of service as a valuable asset. From gaining discipline to learning how to weather a crisis, they carry lessons learned, work habits and best practices into their career as financial planners."The military shaped me in a distinct way," said Reid Hartsfield, a certified financial planner in Jacksonville, Fla. "It makes you think differently. It teaches you to solve problems."Hartsfield spent 10 years in the Navy, including stints on fast-attack, nuclear-powered submarines. His job required that he become a quick learner."With only 130 crew on a sub, you wear a bunch of different hats," he said. "You have to know a little bit about a lot of stuff so that you can fill in for someone in a pinch if you had to."Thanks to frequent military drills, Hartsfield learned to think ahead. He mentally prepared for flooding or fire on a sub and rehearsed what actions to take to mitigate the damage.Throughout his naval training, he engaged in "what if" thinking. Anticipating what he'd do under ever-changing conditions has made him a better advisor who understands the value of scenario planning.When meeting with clients, he likes to pose lots of hypothetical questions such as, "If your partner dies, what will happen to your assets?" or "What if your portfolio takes a severe hit?"Wealth management is easy when everything's rosy. But challenges arise when obstacles or irregularities threaten to interfere with a client's long-term financial plan and retirement.Hartsfield's military training helps him solve client problems in a systematic manner. He learned in the Navy to identify an anomaly, such as low pH level in the reactor coolant, and determine the cause. Similarly, he addresses a client's complex estate plan or cash flow issue with analytical precision."You have to go through a progression of stuff to figure it out," he said. "It prevents you from making assumptions."The ability to diagnose a complicated situation with clear-eyed, rigorous analysis is especially useful in an unpredictable world. If you let biases or hunches supplant careful observation, you can draw faulty conclusions and lead clients astray.In his 26 years in the U.S. Army, Russ Robertson gained an appreciation of standard operating procedures. Now a certified financial planner in Springfield, Va., Robertson says that having step-by-step protocols to manage important activities invariably improves results."Standard operating procedures make you more organized when chaos swirls around you," he said. "Things are a lot calmer because of that."When undergoing routine audits at his advisory firm, Robertson follows a checklist. It's a lesson he learned as an Army colonel."It makes inspections easier," he said. "We give inspectors our checklist and say, 'Here you go.' Then we get back to work."Serving in the military can resemble an extended exercise in stress management. To cope with sudden crises, cadets learn how to think quickly and fix what's broken."Nobody makes good decisions under stress," said Sean Pearson, a certified financial planner in Conshohocken, Pa. He has served in the Pennsylvania National Guard for 19 years.Stationed in Iraq, Pearson recalls donning his chemical-protection suit as air-raid sirens blared. While waiting for incoming missiles, he knew that he'd resume his duties after the threat passed."You have to have patience under fire and stick with your plan," he said. "I tell my clients, 'Let's create a plan and stick to that plan, even under stress.'"He finds that many individuals face periods of financial stress. If markets plummet, for instance, they may impulsively seek to abandon their long-established investment strategy."I learned from the military to persevere through unpleasant stuff," said Pearson, who works for Ameriprise Financial Services. "Things get better. Stress dissipates over time. I'll tell clients, 'We're five years into a 20-year plan. What you're feeling right now is temporary.'"In addition, the military instilled in Pearson an eagerness to expand his knowledge. Going through basic training and officer school, Pearson remembers the constant focus on absorbing and retaining new information such as details about certain weapon systems.He learned that after digesting new information, the next step was applying it and demonstrating technical prowess. Then he would teach others."It's like being an advisor where I keep learning," he said. "I got an MBA. I learned about insurance. From the military, you get the discipline to pursue lifelong learning and then share what you know."RELATED:How Advisors Coach Retirees To Avoid Wasting Money On Costly BuysEager To Avoid Burning Out, Advisors Maintain A Fresh PerspectiveAdvisors Guide Clients Through The Complexities Of Social Security

Shampoo tycoon Paula Kent Meehan chased silver-screen dreams. Then her star bubble burst. "After painfully coming to the conclusion Hollywood wasn't going to make me the next Joan Crawford, I wanted to control my own destiny," she said.Meehan (1931-2014) ended up turning heads in the business world.With $3,000 earned from acting jobs — equivalent to $23,500 today — she launched hair-care startup Redken Laboratories in 1961. The shampoo firm lathered industry stalwarts like Clairol and took 20% of the U.S. hair-care market by 1980.In 1993, Meehan sold the firm — which tallied $165 million in sales that year — to a L'Oreal (LRLCY) American subsidiary for an undisclosed sum."Although Paula Kent Meehan did not achieve her ambition to be a Hollywood star, she launched one of the most influential American beauty startups of the 1960s and 1970s," Geoffrey Jones, author of "Beauty Imagined: A History of the Global Beauty Industry," told IBD.Meehan restyled the industry by applying highbrow science to hair care products. The company's concoctions — formulated by partner and chemist Jheri Redding — promised to make tresses healthier."Simultaneously, she decided not to compete with incumbents in department stores and drugstores, but instead sell directly to the professional salon channel," said Jones.That move elevated the role of stylists, whom Meehan trained to market her wares. Competitors rushed to copy the approach.Good Look"It's a model of how a crowded and quite mature market can be shifted and reshaped by a new entrepreneurial entrant," Jones said.As a businesswoman, Meehan shone. "Paula Kent was a truly inspiring woman who transformed the hair care industry," said Shane Wolf, Redken Worldwide general manager. "With her great passion and entrepreneurial spirit, she touched the hearts and minds of so many people."Meehan led the firm for decades — partner Redding sold his stake in the mid-1960s and launched competing firms — and maintained a high profile in business and philanthropy until her death at age 82."Like any company, Redken had its ups and downs but never once experienced a losing year, so we had a good reputation on Wall Street," she told the Beverly Hills Courier.She was born Paula Baer in that Los Angeles enclave to accountant Richard Baer and housewife Lois.The California girl began acting at age 12 and dropped out of school at 15 to marry beau Donald Slocum.A divorced mother by age 17, Paula made ends meet as a secretary, gas station attendant and actress. Her stage name: Paula Kent.She appeared in commercials and won bit parts in TV shows, peaking with a recurring role as a restaurant hatcheck girl on the 1960s detective show "77 Sunset Strip.""Like every actress, I had to spend many hours with studio makeup artists and hairdressers," she recalled.Unlike other actresses, she had allergic reactions to hair products. That's how the scenario has played out for water products industry leader Pentair (PNR). Its stock has spurted up about 62% since the company tied the knot with Tyco International's (TYC) Tyco Flow division, in September 2012, six months after announcing plans.

The $10 billion stock-for-stock merger created a roughly $8 billion-a-year powerhouse in flow control, filtration and equipment protection. Tyco Flow complements Pentair's offerings and gives it a strong position in fast-growing markets, including the energy arena, while giving a nice lift to revenue and profit, as well as generating cost synergies.

The combo also gives Pentair an opportunity to apply its Pentair Integrated Management System to Tyco Flow's business with the goal of boosting efficiency, performance and productivity — in turn driving earnings growth, analysts say. The PIMS approach, as Pentair calls it, involves a studied set of methods and processes for finding new market opportunities, speeding product development and planning rollouts, while trying to stay lean and sharp as a company.

Pentair was already a big player in the water and fluid systems arena prior to the merger, with products ranging from energy-efficient pumps and point-of-use filtration to engineered pumps and fluid processing systems. It also had a strong position in technical solutions with products that guard and protect electronics and electrical equipment such as enclosures and cases, and made heat management equipment and thermal management systems.
Tying With Tyco
Tyco Flow, a maker of flow control products, added to the mix a lineup including highly engineered valves and controls used in energy, general process, mining and water industries.

"The deal was transformational," said Canaccord Genuity analyst John Quealy. "It gets Pentair into the energy market where they weren't a player, and from a financial perspective it doubled the size of the company."
Pentair posted revenue of $4.4 billion in 2012. It estimates 2013 sales will grow to $7.4 billion.
The rationale behind the deal was diversification, says Quealy.

Prior to the merger, he says, Pentair was "very strong" in water and electrical equipment, but had "de minimis" exposure to energy. Meanwhile Tyco was "very strong" in energy-related applications, he adds, and energy was an area in which Pentair intended to participate.

The combination gives Pentair more exposure to energy applications in industrial sectors and doubles its presence in the energy sector as a combined company, said CEO Randall Hogan on a conference call in March 2012 announcing the deal. Pentair expected the transaction to be "highly accretive" to earnings, adding 40 cents a share to 2013 earnings. It estimates combined company earnings will be greater than $5 a share by 2015, reflecting synergies through efforts such as streamlining operations and economies of scale.

Since closing the deal, adds Quealy, Pentair has "encouraged the Street" it can hit the 2015 earnings target. Most recently, on Dec. 10, Pentair said in a statement that it "remains committed to the target synergies from the transaction, and its $5 per share 2015 EPS goal."
Pentair is able to drive earnings through operating efficiencies and continuous improvement processes, says Wedbush Securities analyst David Rose.
"It's still very early in the process, but right out of the gate it looks like the company is a little ahead of expectations in cost-saving synergies," he said. "The outlook so far is encouraging."
Fruits Of Synergy
Investors believe the merger was a good move for the company, he says, and consequently the stock has made a fairly large move.
"We think there are a lot of opportunities ahead and clearly see the path to more operating efficiencies and cost reductions," Rose said, "probably on the higher end of expectations."

Pentair now expects its "realized synergies" relating to the merger integration in 2013 to be about $120 million, above the $90 million previously estimated, said Hogan on the company's Oct. 22 third-quarter conference call.
"The increase over previous estimates is being driven by sourcing and lean savings in Flow Control and is the result of building momentum around our proven PIMS operating system," Hogan said.
Quealy figures Pentair is in about the "third or fourth inning" of the merger integration process.
Pentair will likely shed more light on its prospects in the wake of the merger when it gives its full-year 2014 outlook on Tuesday.
Quealy says he expects the forecast to be "consistent with other industrials," and that he doesn't expect any "major surprises."
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see 2014 earnings rising 24% to $3.96 a share.

Meanwhile, Pentair is faring well on the financial front, with double-digit profit gains the past two quarters. Earnings rose 34% to 86 cents a share in the third quarter. Sales jumped 111% to $1.8 billion. Analysts expect full-year earnings to rise 34% to $3.20 a share.

"The third quarter met our expectations on the bottom line, as margins expanded 210 basis points to 13.6%," said Hogan on the quarter's conference call. "Price and productivity more than offset inflation, mix was positive and synergies read out better than expected. Our adjusted EPS grew 25%, even though sales declined 1% organically."

But sales were $50 million below Pentair's expectations, he added, due primarily to weak results in Australia. The weakness was not only related to the local economy, but also "a significant foreign exchange head wind," he said.

On a brighter note, Pentair continues to see strength in the residential end market as it benefits from an improving housing market in North America and more spending on dwellings amid rising home values.

Pentair's huge lineup for this market ranges from treatment products that filter and purify water to energy-efficient systems that ensure water pressure is just right. Pentair is also a leading provider of pool and spa equipment.
Sales in the residential and commercial end markets, which accounted for about 45% of the company's Water & Fluid Solutions segment revenue in the quarter, rose 12% from a year earlier.
The food and beverage sector — also a part of the Water & Fluid Solutions segment — remained "very strong" in the quarter, Hogan says. Sales to that market grew 20%.
In the Valves & Controls segment, created after the Tyco Flow merger, sales declined 1% in the quarter. They would have been up 1% if Australia were excluded, said Hogan on the call.
Sales to the oil and gas industry were flat, he added, as many "downstream" customers deferred annual maintenance shutdowns due to high activity.

Pentair is the fifth-largest company by market cap in IBD's Machinery-General Industrial industry group, after Illinois Tool Works (ITW), Parker-Hannifin (PH), Ingersoll-Rand Co. (IR) and Dover (DOV). The group currently ranks No. 20 of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.

On Tuesday Pentair announced that its board has authorized a share buyback program of up to $1 billion through Dec. 31, 2016. The buyback will leave Pentair with another $2 billion in cash and balance sheet capacity for additional business reinvestment or share repurchase by 2015, Hogan said in a statement.

The same day, Pentair said that its board has approved changing the parent company's place of incorporation from Switzerland to Ireland. Shareholders are expected to vote on the proposed change at an anticipated second-quarter shareholders meeting.
The current Swiss firm Pentair Ltd. will become a newly-formed Irish company named Pentair PLC.

The market's recent positive momentum reflects the solid second-quarter earnings season and the relatively reassuring guidance from management teams about the coming quarters. There is ample evidence that the economy appears to be moving into a moderate patch of economic growth in the next few quarters, but will most likely avoid some of the more dire outcomes.

The emerging narrative of moderate but sustainable domestic economic growth, solid corporate profitability, low interest rates and a robust emerging-market growth outlook should help the equity markets drift upwards in the coming months. While I am not necessarily looking for straight upward moves in the benchmark indices going forward, I do envision the overall trend to be positive.

But risks remain to this favorable view; the biggest being reversal in the recent positive, albeit very slow, improvement in private-sector hiring, as well as fears of deflation. Moderate Economic Growth

In-line with recent soft economic reports, estimates for second-half economic growth have been steadily coming down in recent days. These lowered market expectations put third- and fourth-quarter GDP growth rates at 2.2% and 2.8%, respectively. In the first and second quarters of this year, the economy generated growth rates of 3.7% and 2.4%.

An unbiased reading of the economic reports point to a temporary growth moderation in the next couple of quarters with enough fundamental support to resume normal growth next year and beyond. The corporate sector remains in excellent financial health, with growing evidence that firms have started using their record cash hoard towards capital investments. Corporate outlays for equipment and software continue to expand  with a gain of 17% in the second quarter after a 7.8% increase in the first quarter. As such, even though manufacturing activity levels appear to have softened lately, investment spending should remain supportive to growth in the coming quarters.  Slow-Healing Labor Market

While the corporate balance sheets remain in excellent shape, the same can't be said of the household sector. It is this lack of a clear handoff of the recovery from the corporate side to the household side that has been the source of uncertainty for the economic outlook. Deleveraging households in a backdrop of long-lasting labor market weakness remains the weakest part of this economic recovery.

In the absence of a solid turnaround in the labor market, we need the trend of positive private sector job creations in the last seven months to remain in place. Gains in temporary hirings, hourly earnings and the workweek all point to a slow-healing labor market. Reversal of these trends remains a major risk factor to our market outlook.  Supportive Fed
With benchmark short-term interest rates at historically low levels, many pundits are bemoaning the lack of arrows in the Fed's quiver. But counting the Fed out may be premature.

They can engineer quantitative easing through a number of ways in response to the moderating growth outlook and continued labor market issues. The most readily available tool being a resumption of the treasury-bond purchases that they discontinued in the spring. At a minimum, the markets can remain assured that the Fed's continued usage of the extended period reference means that interest rates will remain low for quite a long period.

I was initially looking for an early-2011 timeframe for the onset of the Fed's tightening phase. But now, I don't think the Fed will start removing the monetary stimulus before late 2011. An environment of low interest rates and a supportive Fed are key positives for stocks. Solid Corporate Profitability

As referred to earlier, the turnaround in corporate profitability remains firmly in place. We had solid earnings reports in the second quarter, with year-over-year gains in excess of 40% and more than 75% of companies beating expectations. And not all of the gains have come from cost cutting alone. More than 59% of the firms have beat revenue expectations, with overall top-line gains in excess of 10%.

Not only have second-quarter earnings been solid, but management teams have been coming out with reassuring guidance for the coming quarters. Given the tendency for management teams to be inherently conservative with respect to guidance  often under-promising and over-delivering  the odds are looking good that current earnings expectations will be met, if not surpassed. Current expectations for full-year 2010 and 2011 earnings gains are approximately 34% and 19%, respectively.Portfolio Update

Headline: Late-Summer Trading
Despite all of the news flow, the major indexes aren't moving much. Rather, stocks are stuck in a typical late-summer environment.
Volume has been unimpressive at best. I saw some stocks trade at less than half of the average daily volume this week. It's neither good nor bad, but rather just what often happens this time of year.

Late-summer vacations and the end of earnings season are both big reasons why many traders are sitting out. The uncertainty about the economic environment is also playing a role. Then there is Russia, which has become more militarily aggressive.

In environments like this, I feel sorry for people like Jim Cramer who feel obligated to make something out of nothing. This is a quiet market environment and nothing else. My advice is let events unravel and see what trends develop after Labor Day.
The markets will change from day-to-day; your investing strategies shouldn't.

And part of your strategy should be to always maintain some exposure to stocks. Those who try to time the markets are often the ones who take large losses and miss out on the big gains. Conversely, the most successful investors never stop researching stocks.
Financial Stocks

As I have previously stated, we have intentionally kept financial stocks out of the Focus List. Earnings estimates continue to be cut for both 2008 and 2009 as the credit crisis continues. Banks still don't know what is on their balance sheets, making it impossible for brokerage analysts to do little more than guess what future earnings will be.

The other big problem, that is not getting as much press, is the damage being done to shareholders. The actions taken by many financial companies to stay afloat are dilutive, at best, to existing shareholders. Unfortunately, many firms have gotten themselves into such a large mess that they don't have much choice.

Lehman Brothers (LEH) is talking to Korea Development Bank because it can't find other suitors. Fannie Mae (FNM) and Freddie Mac (FRE) are in need of massive taxpayer help because they have been so mismanaged. These are the type of situations that investors should avoid rather than using the latest rumor of salvation to pick up shares at discounted prices.
Always remember that just because something is cheap doesn't mean it is a bargain.
The Markets
The late-summer environment is evident in the charts of the major U.S. indexes, which show trading ranges.

The market is barely positive this year, lacking in a clear directional move. As articulated in last weeks article (Near-term Economic Picture Less Foggy), we subscribe to the view that there is a net positive tone to the current market, but we are also cognizant of other views out there.

In fact, there is no shortage of detractors who rely on their own set of data and related interpretations to justify their gloomy prognostications. While you know where I stand, it is useful to give both sides of this debate a good hearing. That is exactly what I plan to do here today.

The Bull narrative dwells on a strong economic recovery, both here in the U.S. as well as worldwide, and its impact on corporate earnings and market valuation in a backdrop of exceptionally low interest rates. The Bear argument doubts the sustainability of the economic recovery, fearing another downturn, and dwells on the potential long-term weakness in the labor market. Bull CaseSustainable Economic Recovery: The US economy came out of the Great Recession in the second half of 2009, accelerating to its fastest pace in six years at the end. While fiscal stimulus and inventory restocking helped drive the initial growth spurt, the recovery is on a sustainable enough trajectory to withstand the removal of stimulus in the second half of 2010. The outlook for all the major emerging market economies and other major world economies, including the Eurozone, also remains positive.Solid Earnings Outlook: Following a solid fourth-quarter 2009 earnings season, the outlook for 2010 and beyond looks even better. The finance, basic materials and energy sectors have rebounded, and earnings for the S&P 500 are expected to jump an impressive 31.1% in 2010 and another 20% in 2011. This type of earnings growth is expected to drive the market higher.  Turnaround in the Labor Market: The unemployment rate appears to have peaked at 10% and is expected to steadily decline going forward. While the East Coast "snowmageddon" kept the labor market from producing positive monthly job numbers, the disappointment is expected to be short lived. The weather-related missing jobs from the February report are expected to show up in the March report. But even the negative February monthly report had plenty of positives hidden under its hood. Interest Rates Remain Accomdative: With inflation essentially way off the horizon, and with continued above average slack in the labor market, the Fed will keep interest rates at the current low levels for a very long time. There is no shortage of market bulls that see the Fed on hold through at least the middle of next year. This helps juice up the economy, sustaining the market's positive momentum.Bear CaseEconomic Recovery Unsustainable: The bulk of the GDP growth to date has been driven by inventory restocking and fiscal stimulus-related forces. These are by nature transitory and not sustainable in the long run. With investments and spending outside of the public sector still very weak due to continued access-to-credit issues and ongoing deleveraging, the economic growth momentum will lose steam in the second half of this year as the fiscal stimulus wears off. Bottom line, the economy is on a sugar high right now and is not ready to stand on its own feet. Housing on Shaky Ground: Most of the stabilization that we have seen to date in the housing market ties back directly to the temporary stimulative measures initiated by the U.S. Treasury and the Fed. As these stimulative measures are removed, the housing sector reverts back into its natural weak state, dragging everything else along with it. Case in point is the Fed's stoppage of the purchase of mortgage-backed securities (MBS) at the end of this month. As such, while the actual interest rate increases may be some time off, as the bulls contend, these MBS stoppages will usher in higher mortgage rates in the coming days. China's Uncertain Profile: While fears about the sovereign debt profile of Greece or any of the other so-called PIGS (Portugal, Ireland, Greece, and Spain) have receded to some extent, China remains a major issue. China is trying to control some of the speculative excesses in its real estate sector  in essence it is trying to let the air out of a bubble without actually popping it. China's ability to pull that off without damaging its economy is far from certain and remains a key risk factor for the global economy. Labor Market Continues to Drag: While the labor market may start producing positive job numbers in the coming months, it will be years before we get anywhere near the pre-crisis levels in the U.S. labor market. Millions of jobs in the finance, housing and manufacturing sectors may have been permanently eliminated, making it unlikely those jobs will ever come back. How strong and sustainable can the recovery be if the labor market is in such a weak state?

While I can see merits in both the arguments, my view is more in tune with the bull case. I expect the economic recovery to be sustainable and don't subscribe to the so-called double-dip recession view. On balance though, I see enough merit in the other side of the argument to keep the market from making a clear break out in any direction any time soon. Portfolio Update

The initial batch of second-quarter earnings reports will be released over the next few weeks. I expect profits to follow a similar trend to that of the first-quarter, with the quality of the results depending on the method of measurement used.

For example, the median per share growth for the S&P 500 should be about 6.4%. Aggregate profits for the index (calculated on a top-down basis), however, are likely to be down 7.5%. The difference reflects the impact of weighting, with the aggregate numbers giving more emphasis to financial companies.

Financial companies, particularly banks and thrifts, continue to be adversely affected by rising mortgage delinquencies and foreclosures. Conversely, record-setting oil prices have caused brokerage analysts to constantly revise their quarterly (and full-year) forecasts higher on multiple exploration and production (E&P) companies. These revisions have helped to offset the weakness in the financial sector in the higher median EPS figure.

Rather than focusing on financial and oil companies this week, however, I want to point out specific industries that are not garnering as many headlines, but should have notable results (either for showing good growth or for disappointing shareholders) during second-quarter earnings season.

Record prices at the pump are not translating into higher profits for refiners. Rather, Sunoco (SUN), Tesoro (TSO) and others are likely to report a large drop in year-over-year profits. The reason is the crack spread, or the difference between the price of  crude and oil products such as gasoline. The crack spread soared in May, hurting refining margins.

Refiners are in a tough position of having to balance rising input prices while sustaining demand. As a result, they are accepting lower levels of profitability on the hope that oil prices will fall. Furthermore, the widened spreads will result in gasoline prices staying at high levels even after the oil bubble pops.
SUN and TSO are both Zacks #5 Rank ("strong sell") stocks. They are classified in Oil Refining & Marketing.

Brokerage analysts believe most of the major newspaper publishers will have another bad quarter. Lee Enterprises  is projected to earn just 34 cents per share, a 31% drop from a year ago. The New York Times (NYT  -  Free Report) could see profits plunge 29% to 24 cents per share. (LEE and NYT are both Zacks #5 Rank stocks.)

The industry is being hit by a perfect storm. Readership continues to be hurt by new media. Costs are rising. And the economy is hurting advertising spending. Therefore, it is little wonder that analysts have been cutting forecasts on several publishers.

Full Analysis

Parker Hannifin manufactures motion and control technologies and systems, providing precision-engineered solutions for a wide variety of commercial, mobile, industrial and aerospace markets. The company employs more than 57,000 people in 43 countries around the world.
A Long Record of Raising Dividends

Parker is certainly rewarding from an income perspective as it increased its annual dividends for 52 consecutive years, among the top five longest-running dividend-increase records in the S&P 500 index. The companys dividend yield stands at 1.1% right now, well above the industry average as very few of its peers pay a dividend.
Strong Growth

Growth is also abundant. The company recently announced its acquisition of Titan Industries, which manufactures industrial rubber, custom made and composite hoses for fluid and material transfer as well as related products, services, and accessories.

Parker explained that Titan Industries racked up sales of $28 million last year, adding that this acquisition strengthens Parker's position in the industrial hose market by substantially expanding the product offering and providing entrance into the marine, aircraft, food and dock side refueling markets.

In late April, the company announced record results in several areas, which included fiscal third-quarter sales of $3.2 billion, 14.4% higher than the year-prior $2.8 billion. Third-quarter earnings per share of jumped from last years $1.19 per share to $1.49 per share. The earnings result was about 11% above the consensus estimate.

Earnings per share are expected to grow by 16% over the next 3  5 years, compared to the industry average expectation of 15%. Parker Hannifin offers a return on equity (ROE) of 19%, which tops the industry average of 17%.
Bullish Forecasts
The company hiked its earnings outlook to a range of $5.40 to $5.60 per share. The previous guidance for earnings was $5.15 to $5.40 per share.

"Since fiscal 2008 continues to be strong overall, we have again raised our earnings guidance," said Washkewicz. "Orders are growing in Europe, Asia, Latin America and North America. Many of our key markets, including Aerospace, continue to grow. For other markets, especially those in North America which have been in recession, we are positioned to benefit when they return to more normal growth levels."

Wall Street forecasts are in line with PHs range. Current earnings estimates for the year ending June 2008 are at $5.51 per share, up from the two months-ago level of $5.27. The most accurate projection is even higher at $5.54 per share.
Last week, I expressed optimism about the economy and the equity markets. I also said, however, that we were not yet out of the woods.
The news over the past few days reinforced my view about being cautiously optimistic.

There continues to be good earnings from companies with exposure to economic fluctuations, such as Walt Disney (DIS) and Focus List member Priceline.com (PCLN). Productivity was better than expected in the first-quarter. Many retailers reported growth in April sales. More Americans received their stimulus checks. Finally, the aggregate trend in estimate revisions continues to suggest a declining level of pessimism on the part of brokerage analysts.

On the other hand, oil continued to hit new highs. American International Group (AIG  -  Free Report) reminded investors that the credit crunch is hurting earnings. Eduardo Castro-Wright, who oversees Wal-Mart's (WMT  -  Free Report) U.S. stores, observed that "the 'paycheck cycle' is more pronounced for customers than in past months."

Wal-Mart's conference call on Tuesday could be interesting from a standpoint of how stimulus checks are being spent. Although it is still early, WMT could provide insight as to whether consumers are using the money to buy necessities (food, medicine, etc.), if choosing to splurge on discretionary items like flat panel televisions or saving it/paying down debt.

Keep in mind that revolving consumer debt rose at a 7.9% annual rate in March, according to the Federal Reserve. Soaring gasoline prices and rising food prices are squeezing many consumers. Falling home prices make it harder to depend on home equity lines. For some people, the rebate checks will provide a much needed infusion of cash. But, even among those who need the cash, there is no guarantee that they will make the most fiscally responsible decision on what to do with the stimulus.

From an economic standpoint, we want the rebate checks to be spent. More money tossed into the economy should help to accelerate growth. Saving the cash or using it to pay down debt would be the smarter move for many people, however. Predicting what consumers will actually do is very difficult, especially given that previous surveys have given conflicting forecasts.

Going back to the bigger picture, outside of the financial, homebuilding and retail sector, most corporations are continuing to realize growth. The economy did expand in the first-quarter and we expect the pace of growth to accelerate. It may not be the perfect environment, but there are signs that we should begin to see a gradual recovery.
The major indexes tested their 200-day moving averages, but pulled back. Blame Texas Tea for the failure to move higher.

I would caution against reading too much into the action of the past few days. Earnings season is coming to an end and the Fed is on hold, which means fewer catalysts over the short-term. I think a lot people are waiting to see if the recovery does kick in.

Plus, there the risk remains that the recent upward move was nothing more than a bear trap. I think it was signaled the start of a recovery, but in order to be pragmatic, I need to acknowledge both the good and the bad.

Parker-Hannifin Corporation is a full-line diversified manufacturer of motion control products, including fluid power systems, electromechanical controls and related components. The company operates through three business segments: Industrial, Aerospace and Climate & Industrial Controls.

PH beat the consensus earnings estimate in five straight quarters by an average margin of 8.1%. Moreover, the company topped the Streets estimate in 12 out of the past 14 quarters. In half of the 12 quarters PH surprised by a double-digit percentage. Earnings per share grew 39.3% over the past five years.

On Jan 17, PH reported second-quarter fiscal 2007 profits of $1.55 per share. Compared to analysts expectations of $1.39, the company surprised to the upside by 11.5%. Even more impressive was the 34.8% year-over-year improvement. Revenues came in at $2.5 billion, up 13.6% from $2.2 billion in the same period last year.

Chairman, CEO and President Don Washkewicz stated, Led by exceptional performance in our Industrial International and Aerospace segments, we were able to deliver another record second quarter, and we remain solidly on track for another outstanding year in fiscal 2007.

For the first half of the year, profits increased 33.7% to $403.6 million versus $301.8 million in the prior-year period. Revenues experienced an 18.5% leap to $5.06 billion from $4.27 billion for the first half of fiscal 2006. PH increased revenues for the past nine years while expanding gross margins and growing profits for four years running.

Consensus estimates for this fiscal year currently reside at $6.63, marking a 4.6% jump over the past 30 days. All 13 analysts covering the stock upped their estimates. Profit forecasts for next fiscal year have risen 3.8% to $7.06 over the same period of time, and reflect upward revisions by all 13 covering analysts as well. Earnings per share are projected to grow 13% over the next 3-5 years.

On Jan 25, the Board of Directors declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of 26 cents per common share of stock. The dividend is payable on Mar 2 to shareholders of record as of Feb 15. Within the broader Zacks Rank universe1, financial companies account for 67 of the 135 earnings misses.

First, finance companies, as a group, tend to report earlier than companies in other industries and therefore account for a disproportionate number of total reports. Second, the ratio of surprises to misses does not materially rise for the S&P 500 or the Zacks Rank universe when financial companies are excluded. (Excluding financial companies, the ratio of positive to negative surprises for the S&P 500 is 2.9:1. Including financial companies lowers the ratio to 2.62. The story here appears to be company specific, as opposed to negative trends affecting the sector as a whole. Among mid-sized and smaller firms, weakness in the housing market and the inverted yield caused some to miss expectations, while others faired just fine in the current environment.
